quick_answer.what: Mount Pelée (Montagne Pelée) is an active stratovolcano rising to 1,372 m (4,501 ft) at the northern end of the island of Martinique, a French overseas department in the Lesser Antilles of the Caribbean.
quick_answer.status: Active — last erupted 1929–1932. Monitored by OVSM (Observatoire Volcanologique et Sismologique de Martinique). Currently in a quiescent phase with ongoing fumarolic activity.
quick_answer.famous_for: The catastrophic VEI 4 eruption of May 8, 1902, which destroyed the city of Saint-Pierre and killed approximately 29,000 people — the deadliest volcanic disaster of the 20th century and the type-example of 'Pelean' eruptions.
quick_answer.danger_level: One of the most dangerous volcanoes in the Caribbean — approximately 30,000 people live within direct hazard zones, and the 1902 disaster demonstrated the lethal potential of pyroclastic density currents.

overview.content: Mount Pelée (French: Montagne Pelée, meaning 'Bald Mountain') is an active stratovolcano rising to 1,372 m (4,501 ft) at the northern end of the island of Martinique, a French overseas department in the Lesser Antilles arc of the eastern Caribbean. It is one of the most infamous volcanoes in human history, forever associated with the catastrophic eruption of May 8, 1902, which destroyed the city of Saint-Pierre — then known as the 'Paris of the Caribbean' — and killed approximately 29,000 people in a matter of minutes, making it the deadliest volcanic eruption of the 20th century and one of the deadliest in recorded history. The 1902 disaster was so significant to the science of volcanology that it became the type-example for an entire class of volcanic eruptions: 'Pelean eruptions,' characterized by devastating pyroclastic density currents (nuées ardentes, or 'glowing clouds') that sweep down volcanic flanks at speeds exceeding 100 km/h. Mount Pelée owes its existence to the subduction of the Atlantic oceanic crust of the North American Plate beneath the Caribbean Plate, the same tectonic process that has built the entire chain of volcanic islands stretching from Grenada to Saba in the Lesser Antilles arc. The volcano's andesitic to basaltic andesitic magma composition produces highly explosive eruptions dominated by dome growth, dome collapse, and pyroclastic flow generation — a pattern that has repeated throughout the volcano's 10,000+ year Holocene history. With 54 recorded eruptions, including at least 21 events at VEI 4, Pelée has one of the highest proportions of significant explosive eruptions of any volcano in the Caribbean volcanic arc. The volcano's most recent eruption in 1929–1932 produced a new lava dome within the summit crater but caused no fatalities, benefiting from the hard-learned lessons of 1902. Today, Mount Pelée is continuously monitored by the Observatoire Volcanologique et Sismologique de Martinique (OVSM), and approximately 30,000 people live within its direct hazard zones — a fraction of the 1902 population, but still a significant population at risk should Pelée awaken again.

geology_and_formation.content: Mount Pelée's geological history records repeated cycles of edifice construction and catastrophic destruction that have shaped the volcano's present form. The volcano is built on oceanic crust less than 15 km thick, a consequence of its position within the Lesser Antilles island arc where the Atlantic portion of the North American Plate subducts westward beneath the Caribbean Plate at approximately 2 cm per year — a relatively slow convergence rate that nonetheless generates sufficient melt to sustain volcanic activity across the arc. Three major edifice failures have occurred since the late Pleistocene, each involving the catastrophic collapse of the volcano's southwestern flank. The most recent of these sector collapses occurred approximately 9,000 years ago, leaving a large horseshoe-shaped scarp open to the southwest inside which the modern volcano has been constructed. These flank failures produced massive debris avalanche deposits that extend offshore into the Caribbean Sea and have been mapped by marine geophysical surveys, revealing submarine debris fields covering hundreds of square kilometers. The modern edifice, built within the amphitheater of the most recent collapse, has been the site of more than 20 major eruptions over the past 5,000 years, depositing extensive pyroclastic flow sequences that mantle the volcano's slopes and are incised by steep-walled ravines (locally called rivières) that channel lahars and pyroclastic flows during eruptions. The l'Étang Sec summit crater, currently occupied by lava domes emplaced during the 1902 and 1929 eruptions, sits within this reconstructed edifice. Pelée's andesitic to basaltic andesitic magma is typical of subduction-zone volcanism on oceanic crust: moderately viscous, gas-rich, and prone to producing the explosive dome-building and dome-collapse eruptions that characterize the volcano's behavior. The relatively high frequency of VEI 4 events in Pelée's record — at least 21 over the past 10,000 years, or roughly one every 500 years — reflects the efficient gas retention and pressurization that this magma composition allows, leading to sudden, violent releases when growing lava domes become unstable. This geology makes Mount Pelée fundamentally similar in eruption style to other dome-building Caribbean volcanoes such as Soufrière Hills on Montserrat, which demonstrated comparable behavior during its 1995–2010 eruption.

eruption_history_overview.content: Mount Pelée's eruptive record encompasses 54 documented eruptions spanning more than 10,000 years, from approximately 8210 BCE to the most recent eruption in 1929–1932. The record is dominated by a striking number of VEI 4 events: at least 21 eruptions have reached this explosive magnitude, giving Pelée one of the highest ratios of significant eruptions to total eruptions of any volcano in the world. The prehistoric record, reconstructed from pyroclastic flow deposits and tephra layers in the stratigraphic sequence, reveals a remarkably consistent pattern of explosive dome-building eruptions recurring at intervals of several hundred to a few thousand years. During the past 5,000 years, at least 13 VEI 4 eruptions have occurred, an average recurrence interval of approximately 400 years. The historical record begins with a minor phreatic eruption in 1635, followed by moderate phreatic or phreatomagmatic events in the upper Rivière Claire valley in 1792 and 1851–1852. The catastrophic 1902 eruption represented a dramatic escalation in intensity, producing a VEI 4 event that lasted from April 1902 to 1905 and generated the pyroclastic density currents that destroyed Saint-Pierre. The most recent eruption, from September 1929 to November 1932, produced a new lava dome within the summit crater and minor pyroclastic flows but no significant casualties, largely because authorities had implemented exclusion zones informed by the 1902 experience. The VEI distribution of Pelée's eruptions is unusual: only one event at VEI 1, one at VEI 2, one at VEI 3, and 21 at VEI 4, with the remaining events lacking VEI classifications. This distribution reflects the volcano's strong tendency toward large explosive events rather than the frequent small eruptions typical of many stratovolcanoes.

subsections.title: The 1902 Eruption — Destruction of Saint-Pierre (VEI 4)
subsections.content: The eruption of Mount Pelée that began on April 23, 1902, and culminated in the catastrophic destruction of Saint-Pierre on May 8, 1902, is among the most infamous volcanic disasters in human history and fundamentally transformed the science of volcanology. Precursory activity began in early April with increased fumarolic emissions, sulfurous odors, and ashfall from the summit, and by late April, explosions from the l'Étang Sec crater were sending ash columns several kilometers skyward. On May 5, a lahar descended the Rivière Blanche valley when the crater lake breached, destroying the Guérin sugar factory and killing approximately 25 workers — a harbinger of far worse to come. Despite growing alarm, the colonial governor refused to order an evacuation of Saint-Pierre, in part because local elections were scheduled for May 11 and political considerations overrode safety concerns. On the morning of May 8, at approximately 7:50 AM, a massive lateral explosion sent a superheated pyroclastic density current — described by survivors as a nuée ardente or 'glowing cloud' — racing down the southwestern flank directly toward Saint-Pierre, 6 km from the summit. The cloud, consisting of superheated gas, ash, and rock fragments at temperatures between 300°C and 500°C, reached the city within approximately one minute, traveling at speeds estimated at 150–200 km/h. The pyroclastic current killed virtually the entire population of Saint-Pierre — approximately 29,000 people — in a matter of minutes. The city was not buried like Pompeii but rather incinerated: buildings were stripped of roofing and walls, ships in the harbor capsized and burned, and the intense heat killed through thermal shock and asphyxiation. Remarkably, there were only two or three survivors within the city limits, the most famous being Louis-Auguste Cyparis, a prisoner held in a thick-walled underground cell who sustained severe burns but survived to become a famous attraction in the Barnum & Bailey circus. The 1902 eruption continued for three more years, producing additional pyroclastic flows and extruding a spectacular lava spine — the 'Tower of Pelée' — that rose more than 300 m above the crater before crumbling under its own weight. The disaster at Saint-Pierre had profound consequences for volcanology. The American geologist Thomas Jaggar was so moved by the destruction that he dedicated his career to volcano monitoring, eventually founding the Hawaiian Volcano Observatory. The French volcanologist Alfred Lacroix conducted pioneering studies of the eruption deposits, and the concept of nuées ardentes — pyroclastic density currents — entered the scientific vocabulary directly from the Pelée disaster. The term 'Pelean eruption' was coined to describe eruptions dominated by dome collapse and directed pyroclastic flows, a classification still used today.

subsections.title: The 1929–1932 Eruption — Pelée Reawakens (VEI 3)
subsections.content: Just 27 years after the catastrophe of 1902, Mount Pelée erupted again, beginning in September 1929 and continuing through November 1932. This eruption produced a new lava dome within the l'Étang Sec summit crater and generated minor pyroclastic flows, but crucially caused no fatalities — a direct consequence of the devastating lessons learned in 1902. Authorities evacuated northern Martinique communities as soon as precursory signs appeared, and exclusion zones were established around the volcano. The eruption's VEI 3 rating was lower than the 1902 event, and the pyroclastic flows were significantly smaller, but the dome growth demonstrated that Pelée's magmatic system remained capable of producing the viscous, gas-charged magma that had fueled the 1902 disaster. The 1929 dome, along with the remnant of the 1902 dome, now occupies the summit crater and serves as a visible reminder of the volcano's most recent eruptive phases. The relatively rapid recurrence of eruptive activity — only 27 years between the 1902 and 1929 events — underscores the importance of sustained monitoring at Pelée and has informed modern hazard assessments that assume eruptions can recur on timescales of decades, not just centuries.

subsections.title: The 1851–1852 Eruption — Precursor to Disaster (VEI 2)
subsections.content: The eruption of 1851–1852 was a moderate phreatic to phreatomagmatic event centered in the upper Rivière Claire valley at approximately 900 m elevation on the volcano's southwestern flank. The activity produced ash emissions, sulfurous gas releases, and minor mudflows but no significant casualties. In retrospect, this eruption is significant as a precursor event that demonstrated Pelée's capacity for renewed activity in the modern era, though it gave little indication of the cataclysmic scale of eruption that would follow 50 years later. A similar minor phreatic event had occurred in 1792, also in the Rivière Claire valley. The modest nature of these 19th-century eruptions may have contributed to complacency among residents of Saint-Pierre regarding the threat posed by the volcano, as the living memory of volcanic activity was of events that were dramatic but ultimately non-lethal. This tragic miscalculation — assuming future eruptions would resemble recent mild ones rather than the much larger events recorded in the geological record — remains one of the central cautionary lessons of the 1902 disaster.

current_status_and_monitoring.content: Mount Pelée is classified as active and has been in a quiescent phase since the conclusion of the 1929–1932 eruption, a repose period now exceeding 90 years. The volcano is continuously monitored by the Observatoire Volcanologique et Sismologique de Martinique (OVSM), which operates under the Institut de Physique du Globe de Paris (IPGP). The monitoring network includes seismometers deployed across the edifice to detect volcanic earthquakes and tremor, GPS and electronic distance measurement (EDM) stations to detect ground deformation, and geochemical monitoring of fumarolic gases and thermal springs. The summit area continues to exhibit low-level fumarolic activity and minor thermal anomalies, indicating that the underlying magmatic system has not gone completely dormant. In December 2020, OVSM detected a notable increase in seismic activity beneath the volcano and elevated the alert level to 'yellow vigilance' (the second level on the French four-tier system), the first such change in decades. While seismicity subsequently declined and the alert level was eventually lowered, the episode demonstrated that Pelée's plumbing system remains capable of producing unrest episodes that require careful monitoring and interpretation. Given the volcano's historical eruption frequency — with VEI 4 events recurring approximately every 400–500 years and smaller eruptions every few decades — volcanologists consider another eruption within the coming century to be a reasonable probability, with the most likely scenario being renewed dome growth similar to the 1929–1932 event.

hazards_and_risk_assessment.content: Mount Pelée poses severe volcanic hazards to the approximately 30,000 people living in northern Martinique, with the city of Saint-Pierre (rebuilt with a population of approximately 4,000) located just 6 km south-southwest of the summit. The primary hazards are pyroclastic density currents (nuées ardentes), which are the signature hazard of Pelean eruptions and were responsible for virtually all deaths in the 1902 disaster. These superheated flows of gas, ash, and rock fragments can travel at speeds exceeding 100 km/h and reach temperatures of 300–500°C, making them unsurvivable in open terrain. Dome collapse events during future eruptions could generate pyroclastic flows channeled down the steep-walled ravines (rivières) that radiate from the summit, potentially reaching coastal communities within minutes. Lahars constitute a secondary hazard, particularly when eruptions occur during the rainy season (June–November), as volcanic debris mixed with rainwater can generate mudflows that follow river valleys to the coast. Tephra fall from explosive eruptions could affect communities across northern and central Martinique, disrupting agriculture, contaminating water supplies, and damaging infrastructure. The island's limited road network presents evacuation challenges, as the main highway connecting northern communities to the more populated southern part of Martinique passes through areas within the pyroclastic flow hazard zone. French authorities have developed detailed volcanic emergency plans (Plan ORSEC Volcan) that define exclusion zones, evacuation routes, and alert triggers based on monitoring data from OVSM. The 1902 disaster serves as the reference scenario for emergency planning, though smaller eruptions similar to 1929–1932 are considered more probable. Martinique's status as a French overseas department means that the full resources of the French civil protection system, including military assets, can be deployed during a volcanic crisis.

geography_and_physical_description.content: Mount Pelée dominates the northern skyline of Martinique, a lush tropical island of 1,128 km² in the Windward Islands of the Lesser Antilles. The volcano's summit reaches 1,372 m (4,501 ft) above sea level, making it the highest point on the island. The edifice has a broadly conical profile deeply dissected by steep-walled ravines (rivières) that channel rainwater and, during eruptions, pyroclastic flows and lahars from the summit area toward the coast. The summit is occupied by the l'Étang Sec crater, a dry crater approximately 300 m in diameter that contains two lava domes emplaced during the 1902 and 1929 eruptions. The volcano's southwestern flank is characterized by a prominent amphitheater-shaped depression — the remnant of the most recent sector collapse approximately 9,000 years ago — inside which the modern summit cone has been reconstructed. Extensive pyroclastic flow deposits mantle the slopes from the summit down to sea level, forming the gently sloping apron of volcanic debris on which Saint-Pierre and other northern communities are built. The upper slopes above approximately 800 m are cloaked in tropical montane cloud forest, transitioning to dense tropical rainforest at lower elevations. The volcanic soils derived from Pelée's eruption deposits are exceptionally fertile, supporting banana plantations, sugarcane fields, and tropical gardens that have sustained the island's agricultural economy for centuries. The coastline around Pelée's base features dramatic black sand beaches composed of weathered volcanic material.

climate_and_global_impact.content: Mount Pelée's eruptions have had predominantly local to regional atmospheric effects. The 1902 eruption, despite its catastrophic human impact, was a VEI 4 event that injected a limited quantity of sulfur dioxide into the upper troposphere and lower stratosphere — sufficient to produce vivid sunsets observable in the Caribbean and tropical Atlantic for weeks after the eruption, but insufficient to cause measurable global temperature changes. For comparison, the 1991 eruption of Pinatubo (VEI 6) injected roughly 50–100 times more SO₂ into the stratosphere and cooled global temperatures by approximately 0.5°C. Pelée's earlier VEI 4 eruptions over the past 10,000 years similarly would have had modest atmospheric impacts, potentially contributing to short-term regional haze and minor temperature perturbations in the Caribbean basin but not influencing global climate. The 1902 eruption's significance was overwhelmingly human rather than climatic — its legacy lies in the transformation of volcanological science and disaster preparedness rather than in atmospheric effects.

cultural_significance.content: Mount Pelée and the destruction of Saint-Pierre hold an unparalleled place in Caribbean cultural memory and the global history of natural disasters. Before 1902, Saint-Pierre was the cultural and economic capital of Martinique — a vibrant cosmopolitan city of approximately 29,000 people often called the 'Paris of the Caribbean' for its elegant architecture, active theater, botanical garden, and sophisticated society. The city's complete destruction in minutes created a cultural rupture that reshaped Martinique's identity and shifted the island's administrative center permanently to Fort-de-France in the south. The ruins of Saint-Pierre, which have been partially preserved and incorporated into the modern rebuilt town, serve as a powerful memorial to the disaster and attract tens of thousands of visitors annually. The Musée Volcanologique Frank A. Perret, named after the American volcanologist who studied Pelée extensively, displays artifacts recovered from the ruins including melted glass, charred household items, and the cell in which survivor Louis-Auguste Cyparis was imprisoned. Cyparis himself became one of the most famous volcanic survivors in history, touring with the Barnum & Bailey circus and telling his story to audiences worldwide. The 1902 eruption also had profound scientific consequences: it launched the modern discipline of volcanology and introduced the concept of pyroclastic density currents to scientific literature. Alfred Lacroix's detailed studies of the eruption became foundational texts, and the term 'Pelean eruption' entered the permanent vocabulary of Earth sciences. In Martinique's Creole culture, Pelée (locally called 'la Montagne') is a presence that looms over daily life in the north, simultaneously a source of fertile soils, fresh water, and existential threat.

visiting_and_tourism.content: Mount Pelée and the ruins of Saint-Pierre are among Martinique's most compelling tourist destinations. The summit can be reached via a well-maintained hiking trail (the Grande Randonnée trace) that begins near the hamlet of L'Aileron on the volcano's western flank and ascends through tropical forest and cloud forest to the l'Étang Sec crater, where the 1902 and 1929 lava domes are visible. The hike takes approximately 3–4 hours round trip and offers spectacular views across northern Martinique and, on clear days, to neighboring islands including Dominica and Guadeloupe. In Saint-Pierre, the Musée Volcanologique Frank A. Perret provides an accessible introduction to the 1902 disaster through displays of eruption artifacts, photographs, and geological exhibits. The ruins of Saint-Pierre's theater, cathedral, and other structures are scattered throughout the modern town and can be explored on foot. Guided tours of the ruins, often including underwater exploration of ships sunk in the harbor during the 1902 eruption, are available through local operators. Martinique is served by Aimé Césaire International Airport near Fort-de-France, and Saint-Pierre is approximately a 40-minute drive north from the capital.

nearby_volcanoes.content: Mount Pelée is part of the Lesser Antilles volcanic arc, a chain of active and dormant volcanoes stretching approximately 850 km from Grenada in the south to Saba in the north, all generated by the subduction of the Atlantic oceanic lithosphere beneath the Caribbean Plate. Pelée's nearest volcanic neighbor is the Pitons du Carbet, an eroded Miocene-age volcanic complex in central Martinique that is no longer active. Beyond Martinique, the most volcanologically relevant neighbors include Soufrière de Guadeloupe (1,467 m), an active stratovolcano approximately 175 km to the northwest that last erupted in 1977, and Soufrière Hills on Montserrat (915 m), approximately 340 km to the northwest, whose devastating 1995–2010 eruption produced Pelean-style pyroclastic flows that destroyed the capital city of Plymouth. Other active Lesser Antilles volcanoes include Soufrière Saint Vincent (1,220 m), which erupted explosively in 2021, and the submarine volcano Kick 'em Jenny north of Grenada. The French overseas departments of Martinique and Guadeloupe together account for the majority of France's volcanic hazard exposure.

etymology.content: The name 'Pelée' is French for 'bald' or 'peeled,' referring to the barren, vegetation-free summit of the volcano — a consequence of both the altitude and the sterilizing effects of repeated eruptions and fumarolic activity on the upper slopes. The full French name, Montagne Pelée, translates to 'Bald Mountain' or 'Peeled Mountain.' In Martinican Creole, the volcano is often referred to simply as 'la Montagne' ('the Mountain'), reflecting its dominant position in the island's geography and consciousness.

faqs.question: Is Mount Pelée still active?
faqs.answer: Mount Pelée is classified as active by the Smithsonian Institution's Global Volcanism Program. Although the volcano has not erupted since 1929–1932, it continues to exhibit low-level fumarolic activity at the summit and periodic seismic unrest beneath the edifice. In December 2020, the Observatoire Volcanologique et Sismologique de Martinique detected increased seismic activity and temporarily raised the alert level to yellow vigilance. Pelée's geological record shows VEI 4 eruptions recurring approximately every 400–500 years, and the current repose period of approximately 90 years is well within normal inter-eruptive intervals. Volcanologists consider another eruption within the coming century to be a credible scenario, most likely involving renewed dome growth similar to the 1929–1932 event.

faqs.question: How many people died in the 1902 eruption of Mount Pelée?
faqs.answer: Approximately 29,000 people died in the catastrophic eruption of May 8, 1902, when a pyroclastic density current destroyed the city of Saint-Pierre in minutes. Nearly the entire population of the city perished, with only two or three confirmed survivors within the city limits. The death toll makes the 1902 Pelée eruption the deadliest volcanic disaster of the 20th century and one of the top five deadliest eruptions in recorded history. Most victims died from thermal shock and asphyxiation as the superheated cloud — at temperatures between 300°C and 500°C — swept through the city at speeds estimated at 150–200 km/h.

faqs.question: When did Mount Pelée last erupt?
faqs.answer: Mount Pelée's most recent eruption occurred from September 1929 to November 1932, classified as VEI 3 on the Volcanic Explosivity Index. The eruption produced a new lava dome within the l'Étang Sec summit crater and generated minor pyroclastic flows, but crucially caused no fatalities — authorities implemented evacuation measures informed by the lessons of the devastating 1902 disaster. This eruption demonstrated that Pelée's magmatic system could reactivate on timescales of just a few decades. The volcano has been in a quiescent phase since 1932, though ongoing fumarolic activity and periodic seismic unrest indicate the underlying magmatic system remains active.

faqs.question: What type of volcano is Mount Pelée?
faqs.answer: Mount Pelée is classified as a stratovolcano (composite volcano), constructed from alternating layers of andesitic lava flows, pyroclastic deposits, and volcanic debris. Pelée's eruption style is characterized by the growth and collapse of viscous lava domes within the summit crater, producing the devastating pyroclastic density currents (nuées ardentes) for which the volcano is famous. This eruptive behavior is so distinctive that it has been named after the volcano: 'Pelean eruptions' are recognized as a specific eruption type in volcanological classification.

faqs.question: Can you visit Mount Pelée?
faqs.answer: Yes, Mount Pelée is a popular hiking destination on Martinique. The summit can be reached via the Grande Randonnée trail from L'Aileron on the western flank, a moderately strenuous hike of approximately 3–4 hours round trip that passes through tropical forest and cloud forest to the l'Étang Sec crater. At the summit, visitors can see the lava domes from the 1902 and 1929 eruptions. In Saint-Pierre, the Musée Volcanologique Frank A. Perret displays artifacts from the 1902 disaster, and the ruins of the pre-eruption city can be explored on foot. Martinique is served by Aimé Césaire International Airport, and Saint-Pierre is approximately 40 minutes by car from Fort-de-France.

faqs.question: Could Mount Pelée erupt again?
faqs.answer: Volcanologists consider another eruption of Mount Pelée to be a credible scenario within the coming century. The volcano's geological record shows that VEI 4 eruptions have recurred approximately every 400–500 years over the past 5,000 years, and the most recent VEI 4 event occurred in 1902 — only about 120 years ago. Smaller eruptions like the 1929–1932 dome-building event can occur on shorter timescales. The most probable future eruption scenario involves renewed dome growth and dome-collapse pyroclastic flows, though a larger eruption comparable to 1902 cannot be excluded. OVSM continuously monitors the volcano, and French authorities maintain detailed emergency plans.

faqs.question: What is a Pelean eruption?
faqs.answer: A Pelean eruption is a type of volcanic eruption named after Mount Pelée, characterized by the growth of viscous lava domes within a crater or on a volcano's summit, followed by the gravitational or explosive collapse of these domes to produce fast-moving pyroclastic density currents (historically called nuées ardentes or 'glowing clouds'). These pyroclastic flows are channeled down the volcano's slopes by topography and can travel at speeds exceeding 100 km/h at temperatures of several hundred degrees Celsius. The 1902 eruption of Pelée that destroyed Saint-Pierre was the event that defined this eruption type, introduced by the French volcanologist Alfred Lacroix.

faqs.question: Who survived the 1902 eruption of Mount Pelée?
faqs.answer: The most famous survivor of the May 8, 1902 pyroclastic surge was Louis-Auguste Cyparis (also spelled Sylbaris), a prisoner held in an underground dungeon cell in the Saint-Pierre jail. The thick stone walls and below-ground position of his cell shielded him from the worst of the superheated pyroclastic current, though he sustained severe burns across much of his body. Cyparis was rescued four days after the eruption and went on to become internationally famous, eventually touring with the Barnum & Bailey circus. A shoemaker named Léon Compère-Léandre, who lived at the edge of the city, is also documented as having survived.

faqs.question: How far is Saint-Pierre from Mount Pelée?
faqs.answer: Saint-Pierre is located approximately 6 km (3.7 mi) south-southwest of the summit of Mount Pelée. This proximity proved catastrophic on May 8, 1902, when the pyroclastic density current from the eruption reached the city in approximately one minute. The modern town of Saint-Pierre, rebuilt on the ruins of the pre-1902 city, has a population of approximately 4,000. Other communities in northern Martinique within Pelée's potential hazard zone include Le Prêcheur (approximately 5 km to the west), Le Morne-Rouge (approximately 5 km to the south), and Basse-Pointe (approximately 10 km to the northeast).

faqs.question: Why didn't people evacuate before the 1902 eruption?
faqs.answer: The failure to evacuate Saint-Pierre before the May 8, 1902 eruption resulted from a tragic combination of political interference, scientific uncertainty, and false reassurance. The colonial governor, Louis Mouttet, was reluctant to order an evacuation partly because local elections were scheduled for May 11. A scientific commission concluded that Saint-Pierre was not at risk, a judgment that proved fatally wrong. Authorities published reassuring notices in local newspapers. Governor Mouttet himself died in the eruption along with approximately 29,000 others. The disaster became a defining cautionary tale about the dangers of political interference in scientific hazard assessment.
